text.b: T A B L E O F C O N T E N T S

page.text: 5.4 At the Proximity of Proposed Curb Extension and Sidewalk Improvements ................................ 7
T R A F F I C I M P A C T A S S E S S M E N T F O R 1 5 1 0 C L I V E D R
Y:\Project Files\1526 - Clive Oak Bay Traffic Impact\Report\Clive TIA Mar 27 2013.doc

text.b: 1 I N T R O D U C T I O N

page.text: Boulevard Transportation Group Ltd. was retained by JN Development Group to undertake a traffic
impact study for the proposed residential development at 1510 Clive Drive in Oak Bay. The study
identifies the development traffic impacts to the surrounding roadway network and evaluates the need
for improvements required from a vehicular capacity perspective. The study also reviews safety and
sight distance at the intersection of Oak Bay Ave & Clive Dr. Based on the study findings, conclusions

text.b: 1 . 1 S t u d y A r e a

page.text: The study area encompasses Clive Dr and Oak Bay Ave. See Figure 1 for the study area and site

text.b: 2 B A C K G R O U N D
2 . 1 L a n d U s e

page.text: The existing development at 1510 Clive Drive is an eight unit, two-story apartment building located at
the east end of Oak Bay Village. The site is 12,000 sq.ft. and is comprised of two lots on the northwest
corner of Oak Bay Ave and Clive Drive, one block east of the main intersection of Oak Bay Avenue
and Monterey Avenue. It is part of the transitional buffer of multi-family residential that surrounds the
commercial centre of the Village. The property is currently zoned RM-3 for multi-unit residential use.

text.b: 2 . 2 P r o p o s e d D e v e l o p m e n t

page.text: The proposed development is to include 19 rental units (up from an existing 8 units on the site).
Residential pedestrian and vehicle entry points will be located on Clive Drive (not Oak Bay frontage).
This study is based on a multi-unit building that provides rental accommodation in perpetuity.

text.b: 2 . 3 R o a d N e t w o r k a n d S i t e A c c e s s

page.text: Clive Dr is a local dead-end road, with all vehicle access to/from Oak Bay Ave. Clive Dr is stop-
controlled at Oak Bay Ave. Oak Bay Ave is a major route through Oak Bay, and has two travel lanes
and on-street parking on the north side only in the vicinity of Clive Dr. It has a posted speed limit of 40
km/h, and also has sidewalks on both sides (whereas Clive Dr does not currently have sidewalks).
Residential pedestrian and vehicle entry points will be located off of Clive Drive (not Oak Bay
T R A F F I C I M P A C T A S S E S S M E N T F O R 1 5 1 0 C L I V E D R
Y:\Project Files\1526 - Clive Oak Bay Traffic Impact\Report\Clive TIA Mar 27 2013.doc

text.b: 2 . 4 T r a f f i c C o u n t s
2 . 4 . 1 M a n u a l C o u n t s – M a y 2 0 1 3

page.text: Traffic counts were undertaken during the AM and Saturday peak hours at Oak Bay Ave & Clive Dr
by Boulevard Transportation Group on March 14 2013 from 7:30 to 8:30 am (Thursday) and March 16
2013 from 12:30 to 1:30 pm (Saturday). These were the time periods requested for review as being of
The observed traffic volumes are consistent with a typical collector road on Oak Bay Ave and a very
low volume local road on Clive Dr. Several u-turning vehicles were observed per peak hour at the
intersection, however, where eastbound vehicles pulled u-turns to travel westbound. This is currently a
feasible manoeuvre for some vehicles owing to the current width of Oak Bay Ave.

text.b: 2 . 4 . 2 S u m m e r T r a f f i c E f f e c t s

page.text: A specific concern was the potential adverse traffic operations in the summertime, due to perceived
summertime increases in traffic volume on Oak Bay Ave.
While there was not any available seasonal traffic counts directly at Oak Bay Ave and Clive Dr, counts
were available for Oak Bay Ave in the section between Foul Bay Road and Richmond Road. While the
volumes, in terms of total magnitude, in this section do not directly correspond to the volumes at Clive
Dr, the seasonal patterns are similar and are appropriate for providing a comparison point.
Three counts were available for comparison: 1) an AM peak hour count (7:45 to 8:45) from October
2006, 2) an AM peak hour count (7:45 to 8:45) from July 2009, and 3) a 24-hour tube count from
The comparison of the October and July AM is as follows:
October (2006): two way volume 1045 vehicles per hour
July (2009): two way volume 704 vehicles per hour
Based on this comparison, there is actually more traffic on Oak Bay Ave in October than in the
summer. To investigate further, the 2011 August 24-hour count summer count was reviewed as well.
August (2011): two way volume 725 vehicles per hour (8AM), or peak of 1003 vehicles per
T R A F F I C I M P A C T A S S E S S M E N T F O R 1 5 1 0 C L I V E D R
Y:\Project Files\1526 - Clive Oak Bay Traffic Impact\Report\Clive TIA Mar 27 2013.doc
The 2011 summer count results are consistent with the 2009 July count in the AM peak hour (less than
the October AM count), and even the busiest hour of the day in the August count (11 AM) is less than
the October AM peak hour count in the same section of road. Therefore, even when comparing the
peak hour of the day, the counts on Oak Bay Ave are greater in October, or off-summer months. The
period of greatest concern from a capacity and operations perspective is therefore not the summer
period but the off-summer period. See Appendix A for traffic count summaries.

text.b: 3 E X I S T I N G T R A F F I C C O N D I T I O N S
3 . 1 S y n c h r o M o d e l l i n g S o f t w a r e D e s c r i p t i o n

page.text: Synchro and SimTraffic form a two-part software program that model and simulate traffic conditions.
Synchro uses the Highway Capacity Manual methodology, while SimTraffic integrates established
driver behaviours and characteristics to simulate actual conditions by randomly assigning vehicle
travelling through the road network. Synchro analysis results yield measures of effectiveness – Level
of Service (LOS), queue lengths and delays. Delays and the type of traffic control are used to
determine the LOS letter grade, from LOS A (excellent operations) to LOS F (unstable/failing). LOS C
or better is considered acceptable operations, while LOS D is considered to be on the threshold
between acceptable and unacceptable operations. A full description of Synchro and SimTraffic is

text.b: 3 . 2 E x i s t i n g P e a k H o u r T r a f f i c C o n d i t i o n s

page.text: Based on the traffic counts (AM/Saturday), the LOS exiting Clive Drive is currently LOS B and is
LOS A on Clive Ave in both time periods. See Figure 2 for existing peak hour conditions.
T R A F F I C I M P A C T A S S E S S M E N T F O R 1 5 1 0 C L I V E D R

text.b: 4 P O S T D E V E L O P M E N T T R A F F I C C O N D I T I O N S
4 . 1 T r i p G e n e r a t i o n

page.text: Trips were estimated for the site based on the proposed land use and the Institute of Transportation
Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation Manual (9th Edition). There are 19 units proposed and 8 units
existing; therefore, there will be 11 additional units with the development, which need to be considered
in terms of added trip generation. See Tables 1 and 2 for trip generation details.

text.b: T a b l e 1 : A M P e a k H o u r T r i p G e n e r a t i o n
T a b l e 2 : S a t u r d a y P e a k H o u r T r i p G e n e r a t i o n

page.text: The proposed development will result in five (5) additional peak hour trips, in both the AM and

text.b: 4 . 2 T r i p A s s i g n m e n t

page.text: The trips were assigned to the road network based on the following assumptions:
In the AM peak hour, two outbound trips went to westbound Oak Bay Ave, one outbound trip
went to eastbound Oak Bay Ave, and inbound trips came from the west leg of Oak Bay Ave
In the Saturday peak hour, all outbound trips went to westbound Oak Bay Ave, and for
inbound trips two originated from the west leg and one from the east leg of Oak Bay Ave.
T R A F F I C I M P A C T A S S E S S M E N T F O R 1 5 1 0 C L I V E D R
Y:\Project Files\1526 - Clive Oak Bay Traffic Impact\Report\Clive TIA Mar 27 2013.doc

text.b: 4 . 3 2 0 1 6 O p e n i n g D a y P o s t D e v e l o p m e n t C o n d i t i o n s

page.text: Opening day (2016) post development conditions were investigated in terms of traffic operations. A
2.0 percent annual background traffic growth rate was assumed for the area to account for potential
traffic growth on Oak Bay Ave. Figure 3 shows the 2016 post development volumes and traffic
FIGURE 3: 2016 Opening Year (Post Development) Peak Hour Conditions
Based on the review, the traffic conditions on Clive Dr will remain similar to existing conditions, at
LOS B. Through movements on Oak Bay Avenue continue to operate at a LOS A with the
development. The proposed development will therefore not significantly alter the traffic operations

text.b: 5 S I G H T D I S T A N C E R E V I E W
5 . 1 A v a i l a b l e S i g h t D i s t a n c e s R e v i e w A p p r o a c h

page.text: In-field sight distances were measured on March 14, 2013 at Clive Dr. The approach was to measure
available sight distance at the existing stop sign location, from the sidewalk area (pull-up location
possible at present), and from the pull-up location associated with proposed curb extensions on Oak
Bay Ave. The measured distances were then compared to the required stopping sight distance and
turning sight distance for 40 km/h (the posted speed limit on Oak Bay Ave).
T R A F F I C I M P A C T A S S E S S M E N T F O R 1 5 1 0 C L I V E D R
Y:\Project Files\1526 - Clive Oak Bay Traffic Impact\Report\Clive TIA Mar 27 2013.doc

text.b: 5 . 2 A t S t o p S i g n L o c a t i o n

page.text: At the stop sign location of Clive Drive, sight distances looking Oak Bay Avenue is very restricted for
both directions due to obstructions of the existing wall and cars parked. Table 3 summarizes the
measured sight distances (worst cases) at the stop sign location and required turning /stopping sight
distance for a design speed of 40km/h on Oak Bay Avenue. Required sight distances are based on the
TAC Geometric Design Guide for Canadian Roads.

text.b: T a b l e 3 : S i g h t D i s t a n c e s a t S t o p S i g n L o c a t i o n ( C l i v e D r i v e ) f o r
Looking Oak Bay Ave East at Clive Dr Stop Sign Location
Looking Oak Bay Ave West at Clive Stop Sign Location
5 . 3 A t E x i s t i n g S i d e w a l k L o c a t i o n

page.text: At the existing sidewalk location (this location is considered a possible stop location looking Oak Bay
Avenue with a first pulling-up), sight distances at Clive Drive looking Oak Bay Avenue (both east and
west) is still restricted when there are cars parked on-street although the sight distances can improved
than the stop sign location. Table 4 summarizes the measured distances (worst cases) at the existing
sidewalk location (0.5m south of the edge of the existing wall).
T R A F F I C I M P A C T A S S E S S M E N T F O R 1 5 1 0 C L I V E D R
Y:\Project Files\1526 - Clive Oak Bay Traffic Impact\Report\Clive TIA Mar 27 2013.doc

text.b: T a b l e 4 : S i g h t D i s t a n c e s a t S i d e w a l k L o c a t i o n ( 0 . 5 m o f f W a l l ) f o r
5 . 4 A t t h e P r o x i m i t y o f P r o p o s e d C u r b E x t e n s i o n a n d S i d e w a l k
I m p r o v e m e n t s

page.text: This observation location was selected based on the proposed site frontage improvements, where a
curb extension would be installed at the corner of Clive Dr and Oak Bay Ave. The curb extension will
allow vehicles to encroach further out from the stop sign in a protected area, to be able to see if there
are acceptable vehicle gaps on Oak Bay Ave. Table 5 summarizes the measured distances at 1.5m
south of the edge of existing sidewalk.

text.b: T a b l e 5 : S i g h t D i s t a n c e s a t S i d e w a l k L o c a t i o n ( 0 . 5 m o f f W a l l ) f o r

page.text: T R A F F I C I M P A C T A S S E S S M E N T F O R 1 5 1 0 C L I V E D R
Y:\Project Files\1526 - Clive Oak Bay Traffic Impact\Report\Clive TIA Mar 27 2013.doc

text.b: Looking Oak Bay Ave East at Clive Dr Stop Sign Location
Looking Oak Bay Ave West at Clive Stop Sign Location
5 . 5 A s s e s s m e n t o f S i g h t D i s t a n c e s

page.text: Currently, on-street parking vehicles significantly affect sight distances available for vehicles exiting
from Clive Drive onto Oak Bay Avenue. In the worst case scenario where all on-street parking areas
on Oak Bay Ave are occupied, even the recommended minimum stopping distance is not met unless
vehicles move forward over the existing sidewalk and encroach towards Oak Bay Ave. Available sight
distances depend on how much the exiting vehicles move forward when there are vehicles parked on-
street. Of all sight distances measured at the three different locations, only the location with the
proposed curb extension meets all sight distance requirements for 40km/h including the turning sight
The proposed site plan will allow for greater initial sight distance at the stop sign. This will allow
exiting drivers to look for pedestrians on Oak Bay Ave prior to advancing up to the curb extension
area. At present, the corner of the Clive wall obstructs this view.
The existing lane for the Oak Bay Avenue westbound is approximately 7.5m wide and is sufficient to
provide a 2.5m new curb extension with 2.0m sidewalk. With the improvements, sight distances will
exceed the requirements for 40km/h when a vehicle pulls forward to the curb extension area.
Also, proposed curb extension may help eliminate the concern of u-turns within the intersection of Oak
Bay Ave and Clive Dr, as the narrowing effect on Oak Bay Ave will make u-turns on Oak Bay Avenue
at Clive Drive more difficult to execute.
T R A F F I C I M P A C T A S S E S S M E N T F O R 1 5 1 0 C L I V E D R
Y:\Project Files\1526 - Clive Oak Bay Traffic Impact\Report\Clive TIA Mar 27 2013.doc

text.b: 6 C O N C L U S I O N S

page.text: The following conclusions are made regarding the traffic and safety impacts of the proposed Clive
The proposed development is a 19 unit rental apartment building, situated at the northwest corner of
Clive Dr and Oak Bay Ave. This represents 11 extra units over what currently occupies the site. These
extra units are expected to generate approximately five peak hour trips (both am and Saturday peak).
The results of the traffic assessment found that existing and post development conditions will
effectively be the same, with LOS B on Clive Dr and LOS A on Oak Bay Ave. (LOS D is the typical
threshold for traffic conditions to be considered adverse in urban areas.)
The review of seasonal effects found that there are in fact lower traffic volumes on Oak Bay Ave in the
summertime; therefore the focus on analyzing March volumes was appropriate to assess the worst case
The sight distance review found that currently, the available sight distance is limited at the stop sign,
and when there is on-street parking occurring on Oak Bay Ave near Clive Dr there is insufficient sight
distance even if exiting Clive Dr vehicles encroach into the sidewalk area. There would, however, be
sufficient sight distance with the proposed curb extensions, which would allow a car to encroach
further up to Oak Bay Ave without entering the roadway. Also, the proposed site plan will improve the
sight distances at the northwest corner, where the corner wall currently obstructs views of pedestrians.

text.b: 7 R E C O M M E N D A T I O N S

page.text: No mitigation measures are required due to increased traffic volumes resulting from the proposed
The proposed curb extensions should be implemented so that sight distance requirements can be
met. Further, the corner wall at Clive Dr and Oak Bay Ave should be designed such that drivers
can see pedestrians to the west before encroaching into the curb extension pull-up area.

text.b: 2 U-turns Observed from Oak Bay EB to WB at Clive Dr
1 car observed from Oak Bay Ave EB into Clive (for turnaround) and then to Oak Bay WB from Clive.

text.b: S Y N C H R O M O D E L L I N G S O F T W A R E D E S C R I P T I O N

page.text: The traffic analysis was completed using Synchro and SimTraffic traffic modelling software. Results
were measured in delay, level of service (LOS) and 95th percentile queue length. Synchro is based on
the Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) methodology. SimTraffic integrates established driver
behaviours and characteristics to simulate actual conditions by randomly “seeding” or positioning
vehicles travelling throughout the network. The simulation is run five times (five different random
seedings of vehicle types, behaviours and arrivals) to obtain statistical significance of the results.

text.b: L e v e l s o f S e r v i c e

page.text: Traffic operations are typically described in terms of levels of service, which rates the amount of delay
per vehicle for each movement and the entire intersection. Levels of service range from LOS A
(representing best operations) to LOS E/F (LOS E being poor operations and LOS F being
unpredictable/disruptive operations). LOS E/F are generally unacceptable levels of service under
The hierarchy of criteria for grading an intersection or movement not only includes delay times, but
also takes into account traffic control type (stop signs or traffic signal). For example, if a vehicle is
delayed for 19 seconds at an unsignalized intersection, it is considered to have an average operation,
and would therefore be graded as an LOS C. However, at a signalized intersection, a 19 second delay
would be considered a good operation and therefore it would be given an LOS B. The table below
indicates the range of delay for LOS for signalized and unsignalized intersections.

text.b: T a b l e A 1 : L O S C r i t e r i a , b y I n t e r s e c t i o n T r a f f i c C o n t r o l
